awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Role of New Data Technologies in the Collaborative Development of Accurate Health Measures
awd_abstract_narration:
Comprehensive measures of global population health provide decision-makers with an objective basis for setting health priorities, making cost-effective resource allocation decisions, and assessing the impact of interventions. However, producing accurate measures of global health outcomes is acutely challenging, due to both the lack of quality global health data, and the difficulty of producing universal measures for well-being, cost, and other factors that may vary by region. In recent years, the world's foremost global epidemiology study, the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) Study, has initiated global collaborative efforts to bolster the objectivity and universality of their data and measures. The research supported by this award investigates the grounded micro-practices of these global collaborative efforts in order to understand how  global experts use numbers and data technologies to craft scientific consensus and common understandings across cultural contexts. The findings of this research will be disseminated in such a way to aid researchers and policy-makers better understand how large-scale international data collaborations may operate as venues for forging common understandings, negotiating global social goals and projects, and improving the universality and accuracy of health measures. 

This research uses anthropological methods to investigate the social  and technical micro-practices of global collaboration for the GBD study. The researcher will conduct participant observation and interviews  with researchers at the institutional home of the GBD study, the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation in Seattle, Washington, as well as with their 3,500 global collaborators . The researcher will also conduct historical and semiotic analyses of the quantification procedures used by the GBD study over time in order to evaluate how experts balance scientific, ethical, and social considerations and goals while producing and reviewing health data. In addition to training a graduate student in the methods of social science research, this research will contribute to interdisciplinary efforts to understand the social dynamics of global scientific collaboration and the various ways that social goals and values influence the design and measurement of global health data. Research results will be used to create education materials that will help the public better understand the social and scientific significance and functions of specific measures and data technologies in global health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Margaret Czerwienski has completed research for her dissertation “The Role of New Data Technologies in the Collaborative Development of Accurate Health Measures” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding periods, she spent 18 months in Seattle, Washington studying the methods and collaboration practices of a global public health institute that brings together different public health experts from over 100 countries. As a medical anthropologist specializing in the social study of epidemiological data and metrics, Czerwienski was interested in understanding how global public health scientists combine qualitative and quantitative information and evaluations with new calculative methods to create accurate measures of health outcomes for regions where data is largely missing or incomplete. She was specifically focused on what assumptions, calculative techniques, and feedback mechanisms researchers most commonly relied on to craft reliable algorithms for estimating missing data, as well as on the points where bias was most likely to be built into these tools. 

As a qualitative researcher, Czerwienski accomplished the goal of her research.  Because public health estimates are used to guide a number of public health policy and program decision-making, Czerwienski was interested in developing definitions, heuristics and other analytical tools or explanations for lay persons to use when interpreting complex public health measures, especially for particularly complicated calculational strategies where even uncertainty estimates and confidence intervals are have limited accuracy and utility. Czerwienski also interviewed global public health experts and examined the data collaboration policies and practices of the Global Burden of Disease Study, which revealed insights into the pragmatics and problems of large-scale, highly complex data projects involving sometimes contested questions of cross-cultural health data.

The data Czerwienski collected from interviews, methodological materials and while observing meetings and public discussions of experts serves as the foundation for a larger argument she is crafting about best practices for improving the collaborative methods and data practices of global health epidemiologist to ensure more accurate numbers, especially in data poor regions of the Global South. Czerwienski found that there is a need to increase feedback mechanisms and support more robust data collection across the globe, and her forthcoming work advances specific arguments for combatting bias in epidemiological models. 

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Margaret G Czerwienski
